channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Paris: One Year On
item.media:description: A wounded man was evacuated at the Bataclan concert hall on Nov. 13, 2015. In all, 90 people were killed in the attack there.
item.description: This is the story of the Paris attacks by those who lived through them. “I will always live with the fact that I saw ringing cellphones that said ‘Papa,’ ‘Maman,’ on the dead.”
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Donald Trump’s Election Leaves Angela Merkel as the Liberal West’s Last Defender
item.media:description: Angela Merkel in Brussels for the European Summit last month. The German chancellor has been in power for 11 years.
item.description: The German chancellor, who faces opposition at home, is gathering herself to fight alone for European unity as an increasingly divided Continent looks to Germany.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE and STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: After Trump Win, Parallel Path Is Seen for Marine Le Pen of France’s Far Right
item.description: “It’s the emergence of a new world,” said Ms. Le Pen, the leader of the National Front party. “It’s the end of the 20th century.”
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: South Koreans Rally in Largest Protest in Decades to Demand President’s Ouster
item.description: Hundreds of thousands gathered in central Seoul to call for Park Geun-hye’s resignation after a scandal involving an unofficial adviser.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Bombing at Sufi Shrine in Pakistan Kills Dozens
item.description: The Islamic State claimed responsibility for the attack, which killed at least 52 people and wounded at least 100, though some Pakistani officials were skeptical that the group had been involved.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Guantánamo Deal Could Lead to Prosecution in Indonesia Terrorist Attacks
item.media:description: A car bomb exploded at a luxury hotel in Jakarta, Indonesia, in 2003, killing at least 11 people.
item.description: A transfer of a detainee to Malaysia may lead to him and two others being prosecuted for major bombings in Bali and Jakarta.
item.dc:creator: CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: A Deported Afghan Boy Returns to a Land Nothing Like Home
item.description: Massoud Mosavi, 7, and his family were deported from Norway. But he speaks Norwegian and English, and remembers nothing of his native country.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Where Even Nightmares Are Classified: Psychiatric Care at Guantánamo
item.media:description: A guard tower at a now-empty detention block at Guantánamo Bay. The prison, where nearly 800 men were held over the years, now has 60 detainees.
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Secrecy, mistrust and the shadow of interrogation at the American prison limited doctors’ ability to treat mental illness among detainees.
item.dc:creator: SHERI FINK
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Donald Trump Likely to End Aid for Rebels Fighting Syrian Government
item.media:description: A member of the Syrian Democratic Forces, a United States-backed Kurdish-Arab alliance, inside Syria.
item.description: He said that the United States should focus on defeating the Islamic State, and find common ground with the Syrians and their Russian backers.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: International Readers on How a Trump Presidency Could Affect Them
item.media:description: Television screens in Seoul, South Korea, show a news broadcast after Donald J. Trump won the election.
item.description: We asked our readers outside the United States to tell us how the election might affect their family and country. We received more than 800 responses.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Fleeing Gangs, Central American Families Surge Toward U.S.
item.media:description: Migrants from Honduras and El Salvador at a shelter in Tapachula, Mexico, near the Guatemalan border, one morning last month. “It’s really a refugee crisis,” a United Nations official there said.
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.description: Gang violence and economic desperation in Guatemala, Honduras and El Salvador have driven an exodus of migrants that President-elect Donald J. Trump will have to address.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: What in the World: Jerusalem’s Latest Argument Over History Is About Fried Innards
item.media:description: Nightlife at the Mahane Yehuda Market in Jerusalem.
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.description: A recent death revived an old debate over who invented meorav Yerushalmi, or Jerusalem mixed grill, the signature dish of the city’s Mahane Yehuda Market.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: How Do You Tell the Story of the Paris Attacks? You Let Survivors Speak
item.media:description: People gathered outside the Notre Dame Cathedral on Nov. 15, 2015.
item.description: Alissa J. Rubin, The Times’s Paris bureau chief, describes how compiling an oral history project on the 2015 attacks revealed new aspects of the traumatic event.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Blast at Pakistan Shrine Kills 52, Wounds Scores
item.description: An explosion claimed by militant group Islamic State ripped through a Muslim shrine in southwestern Pakistan on Saturday, killing at least 52 people and wounding scores, officials said.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Bomber Kills 4 Americans at U.S. Base in Afghanistan
item.description: The attack on Bagram Air Base killed two service members and two contractors, American and Afghan officials said.
item.dc:creator: FAHIM ABED and ROD NORDLAND
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: South Korean President’s Leadership Style Is Seen as Factor in Scandal
item.media:description: President Park Geun-hye of South Korea bowed in apology as she delivered an address to the nation.
item.description: Officials who have raised alarms about President Park Geun-hye’s adviser have paid a price, and opponents of the leader point to similarities to her father’s dictatorship.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: ‘We Couldn’t Believe Our Eyes’: A Lost World of Shipwrecks Is Found
item.media:description: An image of the well-preserved medieval ship found at the bottom of the Black Sea, one of more than 40 wrecks discovered. Photogrammetry, a process using thousands of photographs and readings, produced a rendering that appears three-dimensional.
item.media:credit: Expedition and Education Foundation/Black Sea MAP
item.description: Archaeologists have found more than 40 vessels in the Black Sea, some more than a millennium old, shedding light on early empires and trade routes.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM J. BROAD

item.title: Canada Today: Dams, Fiddles and That New Leader Next Door
item.media:description: The construction site of the hydroelectric facility at Muskrat Falls in Labrador in July.
item.media:credit: Andrew Vaughan/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.description: Canadians like their hydroelectric power, but while it may address climate change concerns, it is not without its own issues.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Rodrigo Duterte Takes Karaoke Diplomacy to Malaysia
item.description: Mr. Duterte, president of the Philippines, and Prime Minister Najib Razak of Malaysia found time for a few songs at a state dinner, including “Wind Beneath My Wings.”
item.dc:creator: RUSSELL GOLDMAN

item.title: The Interpreter: What Is Donald Trump’s Foreign Policy?
item.media:description: Donald J. Trump in New York on election night. He seems to approach foreign policy as a series of deals, each divided between a winner and a loser.
item.description: A rundown of the president-elect’s sometimes contradictory pronouncements and what some experts say about the feasibility of his ideas.
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER

item.title: Painful Steps Help Egypt Secure $12 Billion I.M.F. Loan
item.media:description: An Egyptian street vendor in Cairo on Friday. The country is struggling with soaring inflation and shortages of staple foods.
item.description: The loan is intended to avert the collapse of the economy, which has been crumbling since the 2011 uprising that toppled President Hosni Mubarak.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Teenager Seeks to Honor Veterans of War by Preserving Their Stories
item.media:description: Rishi Sharma interviewing William Hahn, a World War II veteran, in Los Angeles as part of Mr. Sharma’s project to record every surviving veteran from that war.
item.description: As nations honored those who fought their wars, a 19-year-old in California is trying to record as many of the voices of World War II veterans as he can.
item.dc:creator: DANIEL VICTOR

item.title: ISIS Is Massacring Mosul Civilians as Troops Advance, U.N. Says
item.media:description: Members of the Iraqi police tried to pull a body from a mass grave discovered in Hamam al-Alil on Monday.
item.description: The United Nations cited witness reports of the sporadic use of chemical agents and stepped-up killings, with bodies strung up around Mosul.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: The Saturday Profile: How Zeng Fanzhi Became China’s Hottest Artist, and Why His Lawn Is So Green
item.media:description: Zeng Fanzhi in front of one of his paintings in his studio in Beijing.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: His version of “The Last Supper” sold for $23.3 million. How does Mr. Zeng explain his success? “I only sell my paintings to those who really like them.”
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ
item.category: Ullens Center for Contemporary Art (Beijing, China)

item.title: Sinosphere: With a Cuckoo’s Journey From China, a Mystery Is Solved, and Cheers Go Up
item.media:description: Skybomb Bolt, a common cuckoo, after he was fitted with a satellite tag in May at the Hanshiqiao Wetland in Beijing. By late October, he had flown to Africa.
item.description: Chinese and British bird groups began tracking two cuckoo subspecies found near Beijing to unravel the puzzle of their winter getaways.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Sinosphere: For Chinese Women, a Surname Is Her Name
item.media:description: A wedding photo session in Shanghai. Chinese women traditionally keep their surnames at marriage.
item.description: The tradition of women keeping their names is rooted in patriarchal Confucian values, whereby a married woman would remain identified by her father’s lineage.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Editorial: Doors Slam Shut for Afghan Refugees
item.media:description: An Afghan Internally Displaced Person (IDP) waits to receive rations at the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) donation camp in Kabul, Afghanistan, 08 November 2016.
item.description: The international community is failing to address Afghanistan’s worsening refugee crisis.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD
item.category: United Nations High Commission for Refugees
Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Postcard From the Hajj: A Pilgrim’s Progress: Checking Mecca Off My Bucket List
item.media:description: “Pilgrims surprised me with their warmth.”
item.description: This reporter’s long-dreamed-of journey to explore the heart of Islam revealed surprises, debunked stereotypes and produced one stunning bird video.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Postscript: One Year Later, a Tip About a Border Crossing Pays Off
item.media:description: Laborers transported ammonium nitrate at the crossing from Akcakale, Turkey, into Syria in April 2015. The compound, a common fertilizer, has been used by terrorists to create explosives.
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.description: How New York Times reporting may have made the Middle East just a little bit safer.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and KARAM SHOUMALI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Turkish Dam Project Threatens to Submerge Thousands of Years of History
item.media:description: The Turkish town of Hasankeyf will be submerged under 200 feet of water after a hydroelectric dam now under construction is completed.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: A contentious dam project that dates to the 1950s is more than 80 percent complete, and the filling of a reservoir will swamp much of the town of Hasankeyf.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT
